comment: ..Scandavian....looking to not get into a Sicilian for a changeand see what happens...
..looking for the Icelandic Gambit.If white opens wrong it can be curtains in 10 moves...typically c4 is playedby white then e6, de Bxe6, Nc3 Bb4....etc
...one of the antidotes....
white declines the gambit for development.
...Bishop is blocked now so have to look at Q side finachetto...
...keeping the development going as willlose time finachetto'ing..White can start to untangle a bit here...
want to keep the place open a little..Brings the rook into playand gives 2 open files to aim at.....
White has good solid centre...rooks to the game will add to this....sowith this in mind...
...just occupy them for the mo....
...white is now threatening to remove Nf6, and leadto a nasty attack ( i thought) of d5...with a view to Bxf6 Qxf6, Bxh7 ...withthe knight Rook and Queen quickly into the Kingside...
...droppinga pawn...Doh !!
...get rid of a key attacker...haveto watch out for eventual Rh3
get the pawn back but therook won't be there for long....
....nastyRook...
...i thought white needed to bring in the other rook andcontinue to build...this helps me get a piece into defend.
...might be looking to anchor the bishop into b5
...a4is now  a target and the a & b pawns can eventually be nasty passed pawns.....

concepts.name: passed_pawn
concepts.reasoning: The comment discusses the potential of the a and b pawns to become passed pawns in future moves. While it does not declare them as passed pawns currently, it implies a future scenario where they could become a threat, hence it's valid to classify this as a discussion about passed pawns.

comment: ...making use of the bishop being loose....
....nearlytook the bishop.....after Bh7  Black loses straight away...
...2pawns up but still a nasty attack for white possible.
....anasty fork. White can't take the knight as Qxc2 is very strong for Blackwith Rc1 to follow. White needed to play Qc1

concepts.name: fork
concepts.reasoning: The comment discusses a potential fork involving White's pieces, indicating that there is a threat to be aware of. The use of 'anasty fork' indicates that the fork is not just present but poses a future threat, especially since it mentions specific responses White must consider.

comment: ....black now winswith the next move. As in effect material loses for white and strong passedpawns mean very strong advantage for Black...
...fxe3and Rc1  winning the choice of bishops. Kf2 (forced) and black also hasNg4  to follow. Rxa1 is most likely.
Always a fun line... plenty to happenafter 4... d5
Totally unexpected! I don't like the tactical possibilitiesafter 5. Nxf7 Bxf2 , so I will take with the bishop instead.
I need to be extremely careful of the pressure onthe f2 pawn here, and my mobility is limited. Black has lost the chanceto castle, but has much better development ... I'm out of my depth here.

Now I have an interesting dilemma. I cannot play the desireddefence of f3 because of the pin from the bishop, but can probably blockwith the knight for long enough to play d3, defending the e4 pawn and finallyallowing my c1 bishop to get involved.  It also leaves open the optionof Nc3, but after bxc6 the knight will have nowhere to develop further,so I am not sure if this is a useful move at this stage.

concepts.name: pin
concepts.reasoning: The concept of 'pin' is clearly discussed in the comment when the author mentions being unable to play the desired defense of f3 due to the pin from the bishop. This indicates that the pin exists in the current position.

comment: Looks like black plans on Bxf3, and with a pin on theg2 pawn capturing the Queen with the rook. Fortunately, the Knight on f6blocks this plan, but I must be careful about it.

concepts.name: pin
concepts.reasoning: The comment discusses Black's potential plan to execute Bxf3 and pin the pawn on g2, indicating a future threat of a pin on the knight and the possibility of capturing the queen. This shows that the concept of 'pin' is relevant to the ongoing analysis of the game.

comment: Triple thepawns and play Nb-d2, and this must work well for white as black does nothave enough firepower to break through.
Ah, cunning, I missed this.Now Bxf3 has become a threat and the tripled pawns are avoided, however....
This forces a recapture, and Nb-d2 still works. after13... cxd6 black has removed the doubled nature of the pawns, but at thecost of another - the material difference is now a solid two pawns.
Threatening mate...

concepts.name: mating_threat
concepts.reasoning: The comment 'Threatening mate...' clearly indicates that there is a potential mating threat in future moves. This aligns with the concept of 'mating_threat', as it is a scenario that could occur based on the current position.

comment: 16... Rxf3 17.Qxf3 Qxh4 18. Qxh3 Qxh3 19. gxh3 -- seems ok for white still.
Allowing the capture of the bishop.
Nice, Imissed this combination -- now it is only one pawn and black has a lotmore pressure.

Rxf2 obviously doesn't work until the queen moves,and Ra-f8 is similarly ineffective whilst the rook is pinned. 19. Rg1 allowsNe3 and for me to start increasing the pressure back. Black needs to worryabout the discovered attack on his queen whilst keeping his f3 rook safe.If 19... Qh5 and black wastes move 20, then Qh5 is risky (19... Qh5 20.Ne3 and the threat of 21. Nf5  is large).

concepts.name: pin
concepts.reasoning: The comment explicitly discusses a pin on the rook that is preventing effective movement. This indicates that the concept of a 'pin' is relevant and applies to the current position, making it an actual concept in play.

This indicates a potential threat in future moves, as it suggests that a discovered attack might occur based on the current positions of the pieces.

comment: This looks much stronger,and the play is risky. There is a threat of Rxf2, and this gives matingrisks on the h2 pawn. The idea here is to play 20. Ne3, and if 20... Rxf2then 21. Rxg7  gives good threats back, but the mate threat remains.  If21... Kf6 then 22. Ng4  Kxg7 23. Nxf2 removes the immediate danger, andif 21... Kf8 then 22. Qg1 makes 22... Qxe3 unattractive because of theimmediate threat of 23. Rg8

concepts.name: mating_threat
concepts.reasoning: The comment discusses a potential mating threat that arises from various move sequences, including the consequences of Black's responses. It explicitly mentions 'the mate threat remains,' indicating that the concept of a mating threat is indeed relevant for future moves in the position.

comment: Piling up the pressure, butallowing the loss of the g7 pawn. 21. Rxg7  R8-f7 22. Rxf7  Rxf7 23. Qg1and white can regroup, with Nf5 having become very strong.  21. Rxg7 Kf622. Qg1 and the d7 knight is hanging - this is not playable for black. If Ke6, Ke8 or Kd8, then 22. Qg1 Rxf2 23. Qg4 Qxg4 24. Nxg4 Rxc2 seemsbad. 22. Rg3 seems the only option.  22. Nf5  is also interesting if 21...Rf7 -- I think it is not useful at this stage as 22... R8xf5 23. exf5 Rxf2seems too threatening.
Strange that I would completelyoverlook this move.
This is now ugly. After 23. fxg3 Rf2white has little attack left. 24. Qg1 is too passive, and 24. Qg4  Qxg425. Nxg4 Rxc2 loses a pawn and leaves the knight in a useless position.
The artilleryhas now been swapped off the board, and there is a tricky endgame to beplayed to take advantage of two extra pawns.
Hoping to playh3 with the risk of getting a passed pawn on the g file.

concepts.name: passed_pawn
concepts.reasoning: The comment discusses the possibility of playing h3, which implies a consideration for future moves that might create a passed pawn on the g-file. It indicates an intention or hope for a potential scenario where a passed pawn could be established, classifying it as a future context.

comment: If 31... d4 then 32.Nd5 and white can create a bigforce of pawns on the queenside. Black cannot advance with e4, and theknight will be hard pressed to look after both sides at once.  31... dxc432. dxc4 seems a lot better, but it is still a guaranteed passed pawn onthe c file, with good support on the a and b files.

concepts.name: passed_pawn
concepts.reasoning: The comment discusses the possibility of a passed pawn on the c file after a sequence of moves. It implies that if certain moves are played, White will create a passed pawn, indicating a future scenario rather than the immediate state of the board.

comment: This seems muchbetter for white, black has a hard time now.
This is thefinal nail. There is simply nothing black can do with the knights off theboard, and white _will_ queen on one side or the other
Game annotation for team benefit --
Never really playedthe Najdorf before, but I need to have more of a repertoire than just theDragon on my black Sicilian play.

I'mnot overly keen on this for black. It's quite highly played in the database,and seems fairly even, but the d6 pawn seems to be a long term weaknessand development if anything slightly favours white.
The d6 pawn is proving to be a realthorn in my side, and I am very restricted here... this does not seem agood choice of opening.

Now whitehas a full passed pawn, and black has little compensation for it. Tornbetween Rd8 to threaten the d5 pawn, Bd6 to hold rank and improve queenmobility, and c4 to prevent white playing c4 first.  I don't like c4 asI cannot easily defend it and it gives white the threat of Bb6.  Bd6 allowsme to follow with Qe7 and Nd7 will allow me to start pushing back on thekingside.  Rc-d8 lessens the defence on the c5 pawn, which cannot now havea pawn for support. Rf-d8 makes a later f5 pawn push less effective, andleaves the c8 rook with nowhere to go. In each of these cases white canjust play c4 and I have no threats.  Bd6 with the intent of Qe7 and Nd7seems the only option, with hopefully an f4 push to follow. With the knightand bishop defending c5 and e5 the rooks should be free to get some actionagain.

concepts.name: passed_pawn
concepts.reasoning: The comment clearly discusses the existence of a full passed pawn for white, indicating that this concept is actively present in the current position. The player is analyzing the implications of this passed pawn and its effect on the game, confirming its relevance now.

comment: Desired development complete, it willbe interesting to see white's new plan.
Seems odd - gxh6 is temptingwere it not for Qxh6 and Rg3  threats -- I'll play this one safe.

Ah, this is becoming clearer now. 21... Rf7 is intended, but 22. Bh5g6 23. Bxg6 hxg6 24. Rxg6  is not pleasant - I think it should be ok after24... Kh8 as the c8 rook and the f7 rook can activate very easily.

25. Qh5 seems the logicalprogression here, giving a nasty check with Bg7 . 24... Rh7 25. Qh5 Rg8seems to prevent 26. Bh7 , 26. Rg7, or 26. Rxg8  from bearing fruit, sothis is my aim for the defence of my corner.

The main mating problems are removed, but the danger isstill very great.  28. Qe6 looks like a big risk. 28... Qxe6 29. dxe6 isa huge risk, with the bishop and knight both hanging, and 28... Rxh6 29.Qxd6 seems full of threats against the black pawns and knight.

This is a relief. Qf7 appears to relieve the big pressure on my piecesas the exchange just doesn't do white any favours. I still need to recoupthe pawn loss, as d5 and h2 are now both fully passed pawns, and the extraknight is going to have its work cut out if it gets that far, but thingsare looking better than they were.

concepts.name: passed_pawn
concepts.reasoning: The comment explicitly mentions that 'd5 and h2 are now both fully passed pawns,' confirming that the concept of passed pawns is indeed discussed in the comment in the current position.

comment: Curious, white clearlydoesn't want the trade, but after Qg6 the risks are simply huge. the rookand bishop are hanging, and if the rook moves anywhere other than d1 thenQb1 is mate. This looks very good for back now.

concepts.name: mating_threat
concepts.reasoning: The comment discusses a potential checkmate threat with 'Qb1 is mate', indicating that if White does not respond appropriately, Black could deliver checkmate in the future. Thus, the concept of 'mating_threat' is valid as it pertains to future threats in the position.

comment: Nice idea... if 30... Rxh6 then 31. Qxd7 is not nice.. However, 30... Qxh6 gainsmaterial and threatens mate - Exchange of Queens is now guaranteed.

concepts.name: mating_threat
concepts.reasoning: The comment discusses that 30... Qxh6 gains material and poses a threat of checkmate, indicating a future mating threat based on a potential move. The phrasing 'threatens mate' confirms the presence of the mating threat as a key aspect of the position.

comment: Protects the mate threat, but loses a pawn and the Queen exchangeis still guaranteed.

concepts.name: mating_threat
concepts.reasoning: The comment clearly refers to a mating threat by stating that a move protects against it. This indicates that a mating threat is present in the current position, making the concept valid.

comment: Game annotation forteam benefit --
There arelots of tactical traps to play after 6... Kxf7 7. Nxe5 (Black cannot play7... Nxe5 because of 8. Qxd8).
Black leaves the bishop alone, butnow has dropped a pawn and lost the ability to castle.
Defendsthe e4 pawn and keeps the mobility of the king down. If 7... Kf6 8. Bf5is planned, but perhaps after 8... g6 black can start to mobilise pieces.
Threatens a future Nd5  check, and just generally helps development

Clearly aiming for Bb7, I decided that the timing is right for 9. Nd5, as the exchange after 9... Nxd5 10. Qxd5 is favourable for white -- therook at a8 is hanging and the Queen can join with the bishop to attackblack's king
Chose to avoid the exchange, but doesn't achieveanything solid with this move.

Only two options here -- if 10...Kd6 then 11. Nxf6  is very painful, as it drops material for nothing andallows white to swap off the other knight, the c8 bishop and the queenon the d7 square, whilst leaving white the next move to castle kingside. if 10... Kf7 then I plan on 11. b3 to fianchetto the c1 bishop and attackthe lone e5 pawn. If 11... Bb7 then 12. Nxf6 is possible, but my e4 pawnis in danger, so perhaps another strategy will be required. Nc3 seems passivebut perhaps Nxe5  is strong instead...
The only safe option.

Interesting, I rather like the bishop here, so I will lay a trapthat, in the worst case, leaves a straightforward material exchange.  12.Nxf6 only allows a King capture (before g6 the pawn was possible) now,as 12... Nxf6 13. Qxd8 seems losing.  12... Kxf6 13. Qd5 leaves some interestingthreats. The rook is hanging but if 13... Rb8 14. Qe6  Kg7 15. Qxg6# isa straight win. interestingly, 13... gxf5 14. exf5 is also good as thepawn can replace the bishop in the mating attack if 14... Rb8  Alternatively,13. Ne5  is also strong, with 13... Kxe5 14. Qd5  winning material forwhite.  12. Nxf6 seems therefore to give white a potentially winning advantage,unless there is some trickery I have missed!

concepts.name: mating_threat
concepts.reasoning: The comment explicitly discusses potential mating threats after the moves 13. Qd5 and 14. Qe6, indicating future scenarios where White has winning chances through a mating attack. The analysis revolves around threats White can impose, affirming the relevance of 'mating_threat'.

comment: An unexpected defence. I guess I assumed black would either move the rookor take the bishop. This seems to lose material now as the bishop can escapewith a capture on the knight at d7

Material isheavily lost now, and black requires some tactical counter-play. I needto make sure the exposed nature of my king does not allow tactical combinationsinvolving the queen and bishops. For example, whilst my queen rests ona8, a check with the f8 bishop allowing the rook to capture it is a realrisk, albeit when the black queen is no longer on e7.
The irony is, I had also missed the fact this pawn was defended when Iplayed Bd2, and very nearly played 17. Kd1  Fortunately I spotted the capturein time...
Game annotation for team benefit --
I've always liked theNimzo-Indian as a versatile black response to the Queen's pawn openingwith a reasonable amount of counter play.
White's pawns a quite persuasivehere. I'm not sure I've done a good job developing this line 9... Ne4 seemslike a mistake.
Odd move, preparingfor Nc7 -> Nd5 where it seems quite strong.
d5 is now defendedfrom putting my knight there. expecting to play g5 when needed, but firstI need to defend the e6 pawn.
Planning g5 and Nd5, nowneeding some way to get my pitiful white bishop activated.
That's g5 ....

And Nd5. I now have a great positionfor my knight to sit, and the white knight is largely out of the fight.White's bishop is verging on useless, and he needs to open a file or breakthe pawn structure somewhere to make any ground in this game.

Now to activate my bishop. Planning 21... Bb5 and 22... a6, and thebishop is suddenly a big thorn in the side of the white squares in white'sterritory. Now I need to get generate a kingside attack with the remainingpieces whilst white is stuck in his corner.
Beginningthe approach. if 22... Rf6 23. Nxg5 I think the loss of the pawn wouldbe awkward if the full attack didn't work -- this seems passive but atleast making some progress :)
Preventing the queen from gettingto h5, and threatening the knight.
Looks threatening, but if25. Nxd5 then 25... exd5 locks the position totally and allows me to keepbuilding the attack on the kingside. Certainly I shouldn't be making acapture here.
Continuing the development -- this time getting inthe moves that I really wanted to develop with.
Trying to relievethe pressure, but with the Queen at d1 I _need_ to ignore this.
Likewise, recapturing here would be very bad for me.

Now thereis a simple threat of Qh1#. Possible responses for white are 27. Nh3 (fxg4seems winning after this) or 27. f3 which is more awkward -- 27... fxg4seems to work, as if white ignores the move then 28... Qh2  29. Kf2 g3#is mate  However, assuming that white does not ignore the move, 28. fxg4leaves possible options to counter, including Nf6 and Rf8 (though the a7pawn would hang). Nf6 looks like it loses material to 29. g5, but afterNg4 white cannot capture the rook without mate on h2.

concepts.name: mating_threat
concepts.reasoning: The comment clearly discusses a mating threat with the move Qh1#, indicating that it poses an immediate danger to White if not addressed. Although it also covers potential responses from White, the focus on the threat of mate confirms that 'mating_threat' is valid and concerns future moves.

comment: Aha, captured the other way. I still like Nf6 after playing the checkas it gives more mating threats with Nxe4.

concepts.name: mating_threat
concepts.reasoning: The comment discusses the move Nf6 as a way to create more mating threats with Nxe4, indicating a potential future threat. Thus, the concept of a mating threat is indeed present in the context of future moves.

comment: Blunder.Perhaps 30. Qc2 was required? it is hard for me to see how to launch amating attack if the e4 pawn / square is re-defended.

This is a G25 I played at the Seattle Chess Club recently.  Myopponent was rated around 400 points below me, but the game is very interestingfrom a positional point of view and contains some interesting tactics.
My opponent opts for the Accepted variation of theReti Opening.  This was the first time I have faced this opening OTB andI was definitely excited to play it.

This move is recommended byNigel Davies in his book 'The Dynamic Reti'.  3. e3 can transpose to aQGA.  The typical Reti move is 3. Na3, but this is not my most favoriteof moves.  3. e4 leads to some very fascinating and unexplored positions.

Wisely blunting the a2-g8 diagonal as my light-squared bishop willtake up residence there on the next move.  3...b5? is just outright badafter 4. a4 c6; 5. ab cb; 6. Nc3 Bd7; 7. b3! when the Black queenside issmashed and White has open lines and a lead in development.  Best, however,is 3...c5.
Again, ...c5 is better, taking control of thebackward d-pawn and the holes on d4 and d3.
5. 0-0 is anotheroption, but I am aiming for a quick d4 and a stong central presence.

Black is neglecting development and the bishop blocks the pressuredown the d-file.  A better plan is the Sicilian-like 5...a6 followed by...b5 and ...Bb7, with pressure on the e-pawn.  ...Nge7 is also better.
As often happens with a bishop on d6, it becomes a target forthe White central pawn duo.
Black is all crowded togetherwith no way to exchange pieces.  My next move is an attempt at a cheapotactic.
Threatening to win material with e5.  This is not a moveI would have played in a standard tournament time control.  Objectively,9. Nc3 is much stronger.
Only kicking my bishop to a better square. The immediate ...Ng6 is better, if a bit awkward.
It's clearat this point that the Black king will find no refuge on the kingside.
Advancing the center duo will give me attacking chances onthe kingside, clear the e4-square for a piece and divide the Black armyin two.

Here I felt I was committed to playing on the kingsideand in the center.  A move like this fits in logically with that plan. While White still has a sizeable advantage here, Fritz 10 suggests that12. Be4 followed by Be3 and Qe2 is devastating for the Black queenside.

This move is horrible.  The king is still in the center and this moveonly serves to highlight the weak squares around the king.  Black's bestis 12...b4, when White still has a clear advantage, but Black will getsome play on the queenside.

concepts.name: weak_square
concepts.reasoning: The comment explicitly mentions that the move highlights the weak squares around the king, thereby directly discussing the concept of 'weak_square.' This is assessed in the current position as the king is still in the center.

comment: Protecting the strong point of theattack.  Fritz suggests ripping open the position with 13. ef! Bxf6; 14.d5, with an overwhelming attack against the centralized Black king.
Black had to try and castle then liquidate the center for some much neededcounterplay.  This move removes a vital piece from the theater of battleand allows me to continue my attack unabated.
I decide to relentlesslypursue a policy of centralization and piece improvement.  Fritz still likesthe exchange on f6.
Stopping d5, however, I have complete controlof the board.
Fritz gives this move as very strong, and I agree!
Black's only chance is to keep the position as closed as possible.
16. Ng5 is crushing after 16...h6; 17. Nxe6!! Bxe6; 18. Qh5 Bf7;19. e6!
The Black pieces are in a complete state of paralysis anddisharmony.
Nd2 is also possible, however, I was aiming for apossible g4.
An interesting move.  The pawn is obviously off limitsdue to the opening of the h-file to the Black rook.
g4 is better,however, this maintains the advantage sufficiently to allow me to playfor the win rather easily.
Attempting to exploit my slow play with...a5 and ...b4 seems to promise better practical chances, even if objectivelyWhite is winning.

Again g4 is better, but I was starting to getinto time trouble and was having to make quick decisions.  I was reallyonly worried about blundering my advantage.  Since the position is relativelyclosed, playing a move like this will hardly toss the advantage.
Again...a5 is stronger, as is ...Qc7, targeting the e-pawn, if I ever try toforce through d5.
Finally!
Giving up e4 dooms my opponent. My knights are going to become much stronger than their counterparts.
Already exploiting the hole!
Black is waiting to die!
Aiming to bring every piece into the attack.
Now Black is lost.  The next sequence of movesis entirely forced.
Black is crushed after ...Nxd7;Qxe6 and Bf5!!
Even worse!
Resigns.
One of my favourite openings. I play it oftenwhen I am white.

I am playing d4 against mysilican opponent in hopes of finding an edge before my oppents tacticshit me. My opponent is the honorable Saitek Maestro Master Chess Computer,which is set to level 3. I am not giving my opponent a rating because Ionly know of the maximum rating of 2200 elo for it. I included some annotationfrom Fritz7, noted as the source where applicable.
Theopening begins to form a Benoni.

I have been reviewingsome Capablanca games and have seen this response to c5, and although thisgame is not of exactly the same nature, this move works for me becauseafter 4...exd5 5.cxd5 I have claimed a little more of the center than blackand my d pawn while overextended is under guard by the queen.

Positional advantages for white at this point are that the f8bishop is bad, and the b8 knight is limited to d7 or a6. Disadvantagesfor white are the weak pawn at d5, the minority queenside, a certain lagin piece development. White needs to move the f1 bishop, which requirese4, which requires Nc3. Black advantages are the queenside majority andcastling before white after Be7. Disadvantages for black are the crampedposition and the positional disadvantages of the b8 knight and f8 bishop.

Black opts to delay castling so that a wing attack can beplaced by Bg7, which provides black some compensation in center control.White will have to keep in mind the x-ray attack on the a1 rook and thepotential for an unguarded b2 pawn in that line of attack.
Theidea is to develop the bishop to a square having the most potential andwhere it will not be kicked back as in 7.Bg5 h6!
Keeping white fromplaying 8.Nb5 to double attack the d6 pawn, and also prepares b5.

concepts.name: fork
concepts.reasoning: The comment discusses the move 8.Nb5 but does not clearly express the concept of a 'fork.' It indicates a potential double attack but does not define it as a fork or discuss the implications of a fork in the position.

comment: Opening up the bishop line by pushing the pawn while adding protectionto d5 and preparing for a future push to the e5 square. This move limitsthe choices for the c8 bishop also.
Fritz:last book move.  Me: MCapplies a pin which can be refuted. The question is which is better theknight or bishop?

concepts.name: pin
concepts.reasoning: The comment explicitly discusses a pin being applied by the knight or bishop. It indicates that this situation is relevant to the current position (as it mentions 'me applying a pin'), thus it is classified as an actual concept.

comment: White puts the question to the bishop.

This move does not achieve a questionable rating from Fritz because of10.g4! g5! 11.Bxg5 Bg6 and the bishop can escape at the cost of a pawn,however I think it should at least rate a half a question mark for losingthe pawn, or at least a speculative rating.  Fritz:: 9... Bxf3  [and Blackhas air to breath] 10. Qxf3 Nbd7
The losing moment whereblack does not play the correct 10...g5 move.  Fritz:: 10... g5 11. Bxg5Bg6
White gains a material advantage to complement the positionaladvantage.
Fritz:: 11... Nxh5 12. Be3

In restrospectthis was not the best move, choices of 12.Bd2 or Bh2 would have been better,with Bh2 a preference. The Fritz variation looks interesting as well. Fritz::12. e5 [and White can already relax] 12... dxe5 13. Bxe5 Bg7
Nowwhite must spend time to relocate the bishop.
It looks likethe knight is headed to d5 or perhaps it is just there for support?

With the idea of 15.0-0-0 and if 14...Nf4 then 15.Bxf4 gxf4 16.Qxf4with decisive advantage. I part ways with Fritz on this moves notationbecause I want to set my opponent up for a fall, as will be seen later. Fritz:: 14. Nd2 [keeps an even firmer grip] 14... Nhf6
With theidea of placing pressure on e4 by way of 15...Nh5f6. I smile as I see thequeen standing in front of the king - and fortunately my opponent can notsee me smiling.
Fritz:: 15... Bg7 16. Be2

Fritz:White prepares e5  Me:Now the queen looks a little precariouslyplaced as the rook lines up on target. Obviously this can not win immediately,but there are enough well placed pieces by white to accomplish the goal.I like the move I made over the Fritz suggestion.  Fritz:: 16. e5 [makesit even easier for White] 16... dxe5 17. Re1 O-O-O 18. Nxe5 Nxe5 19. Bxe5Rg8
Black tries to counter the central development by white, butbetter would be 0-0-0 to remove the king from a potential deadly pin. Fritz:: 16... Ne5 [praying for a miracle] 17. Nxe5 dxe5

concepts.name: pin
concepts.reasoning: The comment discusses Black's potential move 0-0-0 to avoid a 'deadly pin', indicating that the pin could arise in the future if the position isn't handled carefully. The reference to a pin implies an ongoing threat that has yet to manifest, placing it in a future context.

comment: Whitelights a fuze to blow open the position.
Any othermove loses fast.  Fritz:: 18... O-O [does not save the day] 19. Nc6 [Discoveredattack] 19... Qxe1  20. Qxe1 bxc6 21. dxc6
White maintainsthe pin.

concepts.name: pin
concepts.reasoning: The comment 'White maintains the pin' explicitly discusses the concept of a 'pin' in the current position where it's relevant. It's not a hypothetical scenario or reference to the past; it confirms that the pin is actively maintained.

comment: Fritz:: 19... Bxe5 [a fruitless try to alter the courseof the game] 20. d6 Qf6 21. Bxe5 Nxe5 22. Qd5
Applying morepressure.
Fritz:the best thing is for White to hand backsome material. Rated as a good move by Fritz.  Me: setting up for the finishof the combination.
Fritz:Exploits the pin  Me: the black queenis lost while mine will escape. Other moves by black would have lost aswell.  Fritz:: 21... Qxc4 [A pinning theme] 22. Rxc4

concepts.name: pin
concepts.reasoning: The comment explicitly references the pinning theme in the context of the Black queen being lost due to the pin created by White's pieces. The phrase 'Exploits the pin' directly indicates that the concept of a pin is actively discussed in this position.

comment: Fritz::Annihilatesa defender: e6
White targets the pawn and knight - bothcan not be saved.
Fritz:: 23... Kf7 [is the last straw] 24. Qxc4b5
The king will be driven from this point. The choice forblack is a short walk or long.
Long.

There were a lotof choices to review at this position and I took some time to review thelines in my mind. It made most sense to cover e8 to prevent the a8 rookfrom lining up on my queen. The downside is that after 25...Bxc3 26.bxc3and I do not have the pawn available to kick the knight so that I can pushd6-d7 followed by Bh2-d6 mate. The black king is locked in place and allthat is required is an unblockable check to apply mate. Unfortunately theposition requires another route.

concepts.name: mating_threat
concepts.reasoning: The comment discusses a potential mating sequence and the necessity of finding another route to achieve it, indicating a future possibility of a mating threat. The focus is on the implication that an unblockable check could lead to a mate, which aligns with the concept of a 'mating threat' in upcoming moves.

comment: Me:Of course I wishI had seen this line.  Fritz:: 26. Qf5  Kg8 27. Qd5  Kf8 28. Re7 Bd2  29.Kc2 Nxd6 30. Bxd6 Rd8 31. Qf7#
The king makes use of the one squarethat allows escape.  Fritz:: 26... Rh7 [is no salvation] 27. d7 Ne3 28.Rxe3 Rxd7 29. Rf3  Kg7 30. Be5  Kh7 31. Qxd7  Kg8 32. Qf7#
White must drive the king away from the protection of the rooks or interventionof the knight, while keeping in mind the available squares to attack theking will not include e3 or e5.
Fritz:: 27... Kg8 [cannot undo whathas already been done] 28. Re6 Ne5 29. Bxe5 Rh7 30. Rg6  Rg7 31. Qxg7#
Forcing move.

There are a few ideas at workon this move, ie, 30.Qe8 Rh8xe8 31.Rxe8 Ra8xe8 32.dxe8 promotes to queen,with check if the black king remains on h5. Another idea is to cover e8from the move Ra8-e8 which would otherwise cause white to spend time onthe rooks and not the king. And also it provides a waiting move for theking to walk into mate. However there was a better line found by Fritz,seen below. I learned something from Fritz.  Fritz:: 29. Qf7  Kh4 30. Qf5Ne5 31. Bxe5 Rad8 32. Qg4#

concepts.name: mating_threat
concepts.reasoning: The comment explicitly discusses a potential mating threat with the line 32. Qg4#, indicating that White has a path to checkmate after a sequence of moves. This makes the mating threat valid and applicable to future moves.

comment: Fritz:: 29... Ne3 [doesn't improve anything]30. Bg3 Rhf8 31. Qg7 Rf6 32. Qxf6 Rd8 33. Qxh6#
The king islured to take h3, in my mind, but MC decides that another move will prevail.Fritz:: 30. Qf6 h5 31. Qf3 g4 32. Bg3  Kxh3 33. Qh1#
Fritz:: 30...Nd6 [is not much help] 31. Qf3 Rad8 32. Qg4#
Providing someimpetus for Kxh3.
The moves are fairly forced from herewith a decision branch available after the next black move.

The other choice of Kf1 results in mate also. Some kind wordsabout my opponent, the Saitek Maestro Master Chess Computer is really niceand plays a strong game even at the lowest of settings, level 3 this time.I have just discovered the settings to make it play stronger at this level,computer thinking on all my time, and will try my next games using it.I will post my wins back here, and maybe some losses as well. I will alsotry the fixed depth levels for calculation training. I chose this computerfor an opponent instead of Fritz, Shredder, etc, because I can tune itdown and give myself a chance to win. What I like is that it doesn't playbadly even at lower levels to the extent that some software opponents do.

concepts.name: mating_threat
concepts.reasoning: The comment discusses an outcome involving mate with the choice of Kf1, indicating that there is a mating threat associated with that move. Although the focus is more on the computer's playing strength and personal experiences with it, it does imply a future scenario of potential checkmate.
